detailedSummary: Object pronouns replace nouns to avoid repetition. Direct object pronouns answer 'what?' or 'whom?': me, te, lo/la, nos, os, los/las. They replace direct objects: 'Veo el libro' → 'Lo veo' (I see it). Indirect object pronouns answer 'to/for whom?': me, te, le, nos, os, les. They replace indirect objects: 'Doy el libro a María' → 'Le doy el libro' (I give the book to her). Placement: pronouns go before conjugated verbs ('Te veo' - I see you) or attached to infinitives ('Quiero verte' - I want to see you). When both direct and indirect pronouns appear, indirect comes first: 'Te lo doy' (I give it to you). 'Le' and 'les' change to 'se' before 'lo/la/los/las': 'Se lo doy' (I give it to him/her/them). Common verbs with indirect objects: dar (to give), decir (to tell), escribir (to write), enviar (to send), mostrar (to show), prestar (to lend). Understanding object pronouns makes Spanish more natural and concise.
whyItMatters: Object pronouns are essential for natural, fluent Spanish - they eliminate repetition and make speech more concise and native-like.

assignments.title: Master Object Pronouns
assignments.description: Practice using direct and indirect object pronouns correctly in sentences.
tasks: Identify direct and indirect objects in 20 sentences and replace them with pronouns
Practice pronoun placement with conjugated verbs and infinitives
Write sentences using both direct and indirect object pronouns together
Practice the 'se' replacement rule (le/les → se before lo/la/los/las)
Rewrite a paragraph replacing all objects with pronouns

quizzes.question: What is the direct object pronoun for 'el libro' (masculine, singular)?
quizzes.explanation: 'Lo' is the direct object pronoun for masculine singular nouns like 'el libro' (the book → it).

quizzes.question: When both direct and indirect object pronouns are used, the indirect object pronoun comes first.
quizzes.explanation: True. When both pronouns appear, the indirect object pronoun comes first: 'Te lo doy' (I give it to you), not 'Lo te doy'.

quizzes.question: What happens to 'le' or 'les' when followed by 'lo', 'la', 'los', or 'las'?
quizzes.explanation: 'Le' and 'les' change to 'se' before direct object pronouns: 'Le doy el libro' → 'Se lo doy' (I give it to him/her).
